channel.title: AP Physics - Newton's Laws - 2
channel.description:
I just need help on this problem here:
1. A boy pushes a lawnmower. The handle of the lawn mower makes an angle of 22[sup]o[/sup] with the horizontal. If the boy pushes with a force of 135 N, what are the horizontal and vertical components of the force?
See here that I don't fucking understand how the degrees relate to the 135 Newtons. So if anyone can help me, I'll appreciate your generosity.

item.title: AP Physics - Newton's Laws - 2
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

  1. It would be easier if you drew a diagram, but let it suffice to say that if the lawnmower handle makes an angle of 22° with the ground (which is very small for a lawnmower imo), the force has an angle of -22° if its initial point is at the origin

|F| * <cos(θ), sin(θ)>

If you don’t like vectors (which you should probably get used to):

Horizontal component = cos(θ) * |F|
Vertical component = sin(θ) * |F|

Note that |F| is the magnitude of the force. I’ll let you take it from there

Read full topic
